subject: Art
title: Texture
description: How a surface feels ‚Äî or how you make it look like it feels.

hook.text: You look at a painting of a velvet curtain and your brain whispers 'soft.' You've never touched the painting, but texture is so primal your brain simulates it visually.

buildup.text: Actual texture: the real surface feel (thick paint, rough paper, smooth marble). Visual texture: the illusion of texture created by marks, patterns, or rendering on a flat surface.

discovery.text: To render visual texture, vary your marks: short hatches for rough surfaces, smooth gradients for glass, stippling for sand, scumbling for foliage. The tool and technique create the illusion.

twist.text: Contrast is key. A smooth area next to a rough area makes both feel more extreme. A painting that's entirely textured feels flat. Variation creates interest.

climax.text: Exercise: draw three squares. Fill one with crosshatching, one with stippling (dots), and one with smooth shading. Notice how each feels like a completely different material.

punchline.text: You can make paper feel like silk, stone, or fur. Texture is touch through the eyes.

quiz.question: What is the difference between actual and visual texture?
options: Actual texture is real surface feel; visual texture is the illusion of it
Actual texture is rough; visual texture is smooth
